CONCLUSION: Violation of Article 6 - Right to a fair trial (Article 6 - Enforcement proceedings;Article 6-1 - Access to court);Violation of Article 1 of Protocol No. 1 - Protection of property (Article 1 para. 1 of Protocol No. 1 - Peaceful enjoyment of possessions)
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE .
CARDINAL . The applicant is a former employee of ORG ( hereinafter “ the ORG ” ) . By an order of the Head of ORG applicant was dismissed from his job .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant brought an action against the ORG , requesting reinstatement in his job and payment for forced absence up to the day of his reinstatement .

CARDINAL . On DATE the GPE and ORG of GPE found in the applicant ’s favour . In particular , it decided to declare the order of CARDINAL DATE void . Moreover , it ordered the applicant ’s reinstatement in his previous position and awarded him compensation for lost earnings .
CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG appealed against ORG judgment . By a decision of CARDINAL DATE ORG rejected the appeal and upheld ORG judgment .
CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG lodged an appeal on points of law against the decision of DATE with ORG .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG decided to declare the appeal inadmissible for lack of merit , so the judgment of CARDINAL DATE became final .
CARDINAL . On DATE the GPE and ORG of GPE issued a writ of execution in respect of its judgment of CARDINAL DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the bailiff instituted enforcement proceedings . On the same date he decided to oblige the ORG to comply with the requirements of the writ within DATE .
CARDINAL . By a letter dated CARDINAL DATE the bailiff requested that the ORG comply with the requirements of the writ .

CARDINAL . On DATE the bailiff received a response from the ORG , stating that it was impossible to reinstate the applicant in his job , since the structure of the ORG had been modified and the applicant ’s former position did not exist anymore .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was paid CARDINAL NORP drams ( ORG ) for his forced absence , calculated from DATE until DATE , the date on which the judgment in his favour became final .

CARDINAL . The applicant sent several letters to ORG and to different officials , complaining that no measures had been taken to enforce the final judgment of CARDINAL DATE and requesting that the ORG be compelled to comply with that judgment .

CARDINAL . On DATE the bailiff decided to terminate the enforcement proceedings on the grounds that it was impossible to enforce the judgment of CARDINAL DATE . In particular , the applicant could not be reinstated because his previous position was no longer vacant .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant contested the bailiff ’s decision before ORG .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG found in favour of the applicant and cancelled the bailiff ’s decision of DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the supervising bailiff decided to set aside the bailiff ’s decision of DATE and reopen the enforcement proceedings .

CARDINAL . By a letter dated DATE the bailiff again requested that the ORG reinstate the applicant in his previous position and award him compensation for lost earnings until the date of his reinstatement . The ORG replied that the applicant ’s former position had ceased to exist as a result of the NORP decree of DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the bailiff again decided to terminate the enforcement proceedings on the grounds that it was impossible to enforce the judgment of CARDINAL DATE , since the structural unit of ORG where the applicant had been working had ceased to exist .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant contested that decision before ORG . He alleged , in particular , that the judgment of CARDINAL DATE had not been enforced : firstly , he had not been awarded the full sum for his forced absence , and secondly , he had not been reinstated in his previous position .

CARDINAL . By a judgment of DATE ORG decided to grant the applicant ’s claim in respect of the payments for his forced absence , stating that the period should be calculated up to DATE , DATE on which that particular unit of ORG had ceased to exist . As to the applicant ’s second claim , ORG stated that the bailiff ’s decision in this respect was lawful , since the applicant ’s reinstatement had been impossible .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant lodged an appeal against the judgment of ORG .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant ’s claim and upheld ORG decision of CARDINAL DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant lodged an appeal on points of law against the decision of CARDINAL DATE with ORG .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG decided to declare the appeal inadmissible for lack of merit .
CARDINAL . On DATE the bailiff decided to reopen the enforcement proceedings .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was invited to ORG made him a verbal offer of a similar position in another tax inspectorate unit , but this offer was later turned down by the applicant .
CARDINAL . DATE , via telephone , the applicant was again invited to the ORG , but he failed to appear .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Head of ORG of ORG sent a letter to the applicant , offering to reinstate him in a position similar to his previous one , that is , the position of a tax inspector in ORG no . CARDINAL of ORG . The letter also stated that the compensation for the applicant ’s forced absence up to that date amounted to ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant refused to accept the ORG ’s offer . He claimed that the compensation for his forced absence should amount to ORG . In response , the ORG informed the applicant that it would consider the above - mentioned sum if the applicant submitted substantiating calculations .

CARDINAL . On DATE the amount of ORG was transferred by ORG to the bailiff ’s account . On DATE the enforcement proceedings were terminated by the bailiff as this amount had been further transferred to the applicant ’s bank account .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant appealed to ORG , requesting that the bailiff ’s decision be quashed .
CARDINAL . On CARDINAL DATE ORG allowed the applicant ’s appeal and quashed the bailiff ’s decision of DATE . That judgment became final on CARDINAL DATE .
